item.content:encoded:
There is a brand new monetary system on the horizon. As evidenced by the 2008 global financial crisis, cryptocurrencies have emerged as a solution given the inequalities and inefficiencies of traditional institutions.

Since the advent of Bitcoin, the adoption of blockchain technology in the finance world has increased the decentralization of financial services, creating a new world of decentralized financial services, also known as DeFi.

In this article, we will take you through what DeFi is, its advantages, risks, and challenges while highlighting some of the top DeFi projects to look out for soon. But first, how does DeFi differentiate itself from existing FinTech solutions?


DeFi vs. Fintech

At its core, FinTech (Financial Technology) is the use of innovation to enhance and replace existing traditional financial methods of delivering financial services. Although it might be easy for anyone to argue that decentralized finance DeFi is the same as FinTech solutions, nothing could be further from the truth.

Sure, both FinTech and DeFi aim to establish financial inclusion, efficiency, and freedom through the use of technology.  

However, one of the key differences that distinguish the two is that FinTech solutions emerge from specific centralized companies. At the same time, DeFi applications are open source systems that operate autonomously without the support of a centralized entity.

DeFi applications stand out from the fact that they take on a new open-source approach that allows many services to be launched on top of the blockchain. An excellent example of how DeFi operates is how the internet, a decentralized network of computers, is designed to be a platform from which other services with a central entity can be built. The internet itself has no owner.


DeFi’s Main Advantages

One of the main benefits of DeFi is permission-less finance. DeFi applications apply practical solutions to the world’s unbanked by offering access to financial services that were previously inaccessible.

Although there exist some FinTech solutions such as Mpesa that have succeeded in encouraging the inclusivity of the unbanked, the data reveals that there is still much to be done. Despite the emergence of mobile money solutions, banks still rely on IDs and credit scores to verify customers, yet most of the unbanked lack these credentials. With DeFi applications, users do not need to have IDs or credit scores to benefit.

Another advantage that DeFi offers is its efficient methods of user verification. Given the vulnerability of financial products to fraud, KYC (know your customer) and AML (anti-money laundering) protocols have been put in place as a solution for verifying and identifying customers. 

However, these methods put the customer’s identity at risk since that data is stored by the central entity collecting a customer’s ID for verification. If a hack was to happen at a specified FinTech company, the customer’s identity could be sold on black markets. 

DeFi applications come to the rescue with a solution that efficiently prevents fraud while ensuring installing a reliable verification process without the need of a customer’s details. 

By design, DeFI solutions are taking trust out of the hands of humans and embedding it into the code that runs the entire technology. This protects the customer’s identity in the event of an attack and makes it impossible for corrupt and malicious activities to thrive on the network.

In light of the current pandemic, DeFi solutions could provide a much more effective and efficient alternative for disbursing a universal basic income from governments. With DeFi, millions of people can get funding from the government in an instant with traceable payments that are cost-effective. 


DeFi’s Projects

Various industries can benefit from decentralized finance. You will find DeFi projects in different sectors, including insurance, merging trading, asset management tools, and analytics, to mention only a few.

Here is a quick look at some DeFi projects out there.


Decentralized exchanges

Examples of DeFi exchanges include applications such as AirSwap. This is a peer to peer token trading platform built on Ethereum’s blockchain. AirSwap’s most outstanding feature is that it operates as an exchange without trading fees. Another one is 1inch.exchange. As a cost efficiency measure, this application splits orders to several decentralized exchanges such as KyberNetwork, Bancor, and UniswapExchange.


DeFi Lending

Here you will find applications such as Atomic Loans, which allow you to lock your Bitcoin in a non-custodial escrow. Then, you can borrow stable coins and lend them out while you earn interest. Fulcrum is another DeFi platform pushing the idea of margin trading and lending to the next level. With Fulcrum, users not only get to lend assets for interest, but they can also get into short or leveraged positions through tokenized margin trading. By this design, Fulcrum makes it possible for users to maximize gains through issuing loans and taking compassable margin trade positions. 


DeFi Marketplaces 

If you are looking for an online marketplace free from the controls of a central entity, these DeFi marketplaces will be a good fit. GitCoin, for instance, acts as a market where freelance developers get to interact with one another and with clients to work remotely on open source software projects. Another one is OpenSea, a peer-to-peer marketplace for crypto enthusiasts looking to exchange crypto collectibles.


Decentralized prediction markets 

With a decentralized finance solution, the outcome of events can be traded on a peer-to-peer platform where predictions can be priced based on the market’s judgment. One particular application in this area is Augur. This DeFi application enables users to vote and put a price on the outcome of events. By this logic, anyone can tap into the crowd’s collective wisdom and make predictions of future events.  


What’s next for DeFi?

As the world continues to embrace blockchain technology, the future of DeFi applications seems to get brighter. As time progresses, the DeFi industry is set to redesign all the services present in the traditional finance world today. 

In the face of crypto and blockchain’s mass adoption, the future will see crypto wallets become the gateway to all digital asset activity. Picture using your crypto wallet as the interface for interacting with a variety of blockchain networks where you can manage your digital assets, lock some of it on an open-source finance protocol or even create smart contracts for your next mortgage. 

While there is still a long way to go to achieve this, significant strides are being made by DeFi developers in sectors such as insurance. Projects such as Opyn are developing insurance layers for the benefit of decentralized finance projects, while projects like Etherisc are providing insurance protocols that enable collective risk transfer solutions. 

There is also a progressive shift towards decentralized governance with projects like Maker Dao showcasing how large organizations can be run by stakeholders who vote and make decisions.


Challenges & Risks

DeFi applications present unique and practical solutions to the problems faced by the current financial system. However, as much as DeFi solutions offer a direct route to the customer, improving efficiency and security in the process, DeFi applications are challenged by speed, scalability, and liquidity.

Currently, DeFi application on public Blockchains cannot process large volumes of transactions as traditional FinTech solutions like Visa. While Visa is capable of 24,000 transactions per second, Ethereum can only manage 15TPS, and Bitcoin can manage 7TPS.  

This lack of speed makes it challenging to scale DeFi solutions to the masses. Lack of liquidity is another problem faced by DeFi applications, as evidenced by the price volatility of cryptocurrencies. 


Solving DeFi’s challenges (Preparing for the future)

Even though the DeFi landscape is plagued by challenges highlighted above, several projects are working towards solutions. 

Bitcoin’s lightning network is a good example of an attempt to make the Bitcoin blockchain scalable by recording some of the transactions off-chain. The Ethereum blockchain is also set to move from a Proof of Work protocol to a fast and power-efficient Proof of Stake protocol soon.

Furthermore, like any other emerging financial product, DeFi applications are in their nascent stage and therefore bound to have a list of challenges beyond what could be covered in this post. 

Overall, DeFi applications present a huge potential for transforming the world of finance as we know it. Even though the current landscape is playing catch up to the traditional financial system, anyone can guess what the future holds if the industry is given room to grow.

item.content:encoded:
Since Bitcoin was created and launched in 2009, more than 1500 different cryptocurrencies, collectively termed altcoins, are now available to buy, trade and sell. Verge is an interesting example of an altcoin as it is faster, cheaper and offers even more privacy than Bitcoin!


What is Verge (XVG)? 

Verge (XVG) is a decentralized open-source cryptocurrency with a strong focus on anonymity and privacy. Launched in 2014 by Justin Sunerok as DogeCoinDark and rebranded into Verge in 2016, the company became famous after partnering with Pornhub in 2018, where it is possible to pay for a premium subscription with Verge (XVG). Verge is an open-source cryptocurrency, meaning it is not backed up by any company. The developers categorize Verge as an easy-to-use currency for everyday transactions. 

Despite having a transparent ledger where all the transactions are shown, the addresses or identities of the users cannot be inferred due to IP obfuscation by Tor (see below). The mission of Verge is to improve on the shortcomings of Bitcoin and provide individual users and businesses with a decentralized, fast and efficient way of performing confidential transactions.


Brief history 

The project was started in 2014 with the aim of rendering blockchain transactions completely anonymous and untraceable. 

In February 2016 rebranding Of DogeCoinDark to Verge took place to separate the project from “dark” associations. After that, the team has been fully committed to promoting the coin and encouraging adoption.

In 2017, a somewhat controversial incident took place: John McAfee, a prominent personality in the cryptocurrency world, posted a tweet about Verge, calling it a good coin to invest in and making a price prediction of $15 for XVG. This, allegedly, led to a further increase in the price of Verge to $0.3, which became its historical high, despite McAfee later withdrawing his claims and even discrediting the currency and its protocol in early 2018. 

In November 2017, CoinPouch, a wallet supported by the Verge team, lost around 125 million XVG as a result of a hack. To this day, it is not clear what exactly happened, as neither party wants to take responsibility, and the account that the coins were transferred to suggests that the hackers might have sold them through an exchange.

Verge became famous for partnering with Pornhub where it is possible to buy Premium subscription with XVG. This partnership is considered one of the biggest cases of cryptocurrency adoption by a totally different industry.

In April and May 2018, Verge suffered from 51% miners (double-spending) attacks. Basically, the hackers forced the system to use only one algorithm by altering block timestamps. The mining difficulty dropped significantly; as a result, they were able to incorporate a new block every second. Verge experienced a total of 3 attacks in a couple of months. 


Verge (XVG) technology

The key features of Verge include:

  • Tor IP obfuscation. Tor (an acronym of The Onion Router, the original software project name) is an IP obfuscation service which ensures anonymous communication across a layered circuit-based network. Tor is integrated in all of Verge wallets, thus eliminating any possibility that the communicating peers can be identified through network surveillance which usually relies on knowing its source and destination.
  • Multi-algorithm mining. Verge Currency uses Proof-of-Work (PoW) mining principle and one of the very few cryptocurrencies to have multi-algorithm support. Specifically, Verge utilizes 5 different hash functions: Scrypt,  Lyra2rev2, X17, blake2s, and myr-groestl. Such design allows for equal access to different groups of miners. Mining is the only way to create new XVG since Verge is not a private company funded by pre-mined coins or an ICO.
  • Atomic Swaps. Atomic Swap technology, or atomic cross-chain trading, is a technology that enables direct peer-to-peer trading across different blockchains with BIP65 support, thus eliminating the need for trusted third parties or intermediaries. In the future, traditional centralized exchanges can be replaced by decentralized exchanges (DEX), which would completely eliminate the need to rely on  intermediaries. By enabling Atomic Swaps capability, Verge takes a proactive step towards a decentralized future.
  • Dual-key stealth addressing. Dual-Key Stealth Addressing enables senders to create an unlimited amount of one-time destination addresses on behalf of the recipient without any interaction between the parties whatsoever. Stealth addresses provide an additional level of obfuscation for further protection of the receiving party when performing transactions with Verge. If multiple users send funds to one stealth address, these transactions do not appear on the blockchain as multiple payments to the same address. Instead,  they look like multiple payments going to different addresses.
  • Verge runs on a Proof-of-Work consensus mechanism and uses five types of mining algorithms: Scrypt, X17, Blake2s, Groestl, and Lyra2rev2. Unlike other anonymity-focused digital currencies, e.g., Monero and Dash, it offers more transparency in public verification of transactions.
  • The block time is 30 seconds vs Bitcoin’s 10 minutes, and the capacity of Verge is 100 transactions per second as opposed to Bitcoin’s 7. 
  • The transaction fee is 0.01 XVG, which is practically free. 
  • The maximum supply of Verge is limited to 16.5 billion coins, which is supposed to provide a more fair distribution in the community and, to a certain extent,  prevent market manipulations, 
  • Wraith protocol. For the first time in the history of cryptocurrency, Verge made it  possible to choose between public and private ledgers while staying anonymous in both cases. 

Technology-wise, Verge does not utilize cryptography as much as its fellow privacy-focused cryptocurrencies (Monero, Zcash etc). The main feature of Verge is the ability to obfuscate the users’ IP address and location using I2P (Invisible Internet Project) and TOR (The Onion Router) network layers. While anyone can view the transactions that occur on the Verge ledger, the participants’ location or IP cannot be identified. All Core Verge wallets offer built-in TOR integration, supported by an additional level of SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) encryption. 


Why not simply use VPN?

When communicating via Virtual Private Network (VPN), the only encrypted part of the connection is from you to your VPN provider. From there on, the communication stays unprotected. Therefore, VPN service requires trust that your provider does not disclose information, logs, and records about your operations. On the other hand, with Verge, the user does not have to rely on any third party for the protection of confidentiality, which makes it more reliable and secure than using a VPN.


Perspectives 

One feature currently under development is RSK smart contracts. RSK is the first open-source smart contract platform with a 2-way peg to Verge that also rewards the Verge miners via merge-mining, allowing them to actively participate in the Smart Contract revolution. The aim of RSK  is to add value and functionality to the Verge ecosystem and increase scalability by enabling smart-contracts and near-instant payments. RSK can achieve the same security as Verge in terms of double-spend prevention and settlement finality, since the blockchain is secured by merge-mining.

The implementation of the Wraith protocol was an important event in the history of cryptocurrency in general. Verge is a stable member of Top-100 cryptocurrencies in terms of market capitalization, it has established several long-term partnerships with important players in the industry, and has an ambitious roadmap. In general, the consensus among the members of the cryptocurrency community is that this altoin has occupied its niche and will experience a bright future. 


Takeaways

Created in 2014 under the original name  DogecoinDark, Verge (XVG) is an open-source cryptocurrency and a privacy-focused coin with a team of international developers. Verge uses Tor and an anonymous network layer I2Pas in order to hide the IP addresses and locations of specific transactions. The block time (and transaction speed) of Verge is estimated to be at 5-30 seconds thanks to the use of SPV (Simple Payment Verification). Recent introduction of the Wraith Protocol upgrade enabled users to send and receive payments completely anonymously across the Verge blockchain via stealth addressing services. Following the update, Verge users are reportedly able to switch between private and public ledgers on the Verge blockchain. Verge offers five different Proof-of-Work algorithms for mining – Lyra2rev2, Scrypt, X17, blake2s and myr-groestl, which significantly expands the pool of miners and serves to minimize the possibility of double-spending attacks.

How to store and manage XVG

item.content:encoded:
What is DigiByte (DGB)? 

DigiByte blockchain is a rapidly growing public blockchain with a strong focus on cybersecurity of digital payments and decentralized applications. Created by Jared Tate in 2014, it is currently the world’s longest major blockchain. The DigiByte currency (DGB) was created to improve on the shortcomings of BTC and LTC, specifically high fees, vulnerability to attacks, poor scalability, low bandwidth, and volatility. 

Brief history

Jared Tate, the founder of DigiByte, comes from computer programming, blockchain, and cybersecurity background. He designed DigiByte in 2013 with the incentive to offer a faster and more secure alternative to Bitcoin. The official start of the project was marked with the mining of the genesis block in January 2014. As there was no initial coin offering (ICO), the project start did not draw any significant media interest. Instead of this, the project was funded through donations granted to the DigiByte Foundation – a dedicated organization in charge of promoting the project at the global level.

The DGB Genesis block contains a direct allusion to Bitcoin’s Genesis block: “USA Today: 10/Jan/2014, Target: Data stolen from up to 110M customers”. 

Some of the main milestones:

  • January 2014: The launch of DigiByte
  • September 2014: DigiByte successfully implements its second hardfork that allows mining on 5 different algorithms. It becomes the first-ever blockchain to do so.
  • June 2016: Official partnership with Microsoft BizSpark

DigiByte technology

What makes DigiByte unique in the world of cryptocurrency is the complex architecture of its blockchain and the tendency towards new technological trends. 

The mottos of DigiByte can be defined as follows:

  • A faster-than-average network. DigiByte claims to have the fastest block generation speed of all public UTXO blockchains (e.g. Bitcoin, Litecoin) in operation today. Furthermore, it was one of the first adopters of SegWit (Segregated Witness) protocol which conferred unprecedented scalability and security to the network. 
  • Security does not have to be the weak point of the crypto world. DigiByte developers believe that its blockchain implementation is capable of plugging the majority of potential security-related leaks thanks to its global-level decentralization involving more than 200000 devices such as computers, phones, nodes, and servers. Additionally, to manage the difficulty stability and protect itself from recurring malicious attacks, Digibyte implemented its pioneering DigiShield and MultiShield technologies.
  • Blockchain implementation needs to be more progressive in its applications. DigiByte is keeping an eye on three key technologies that are expected to transform the world: Artificial Intelligence (AI), cybersecurity, and the Internet of Things (IoT). DigiByte hopes to extend its innovations in security to IoT devices and combine its blockchain technology with AI in order to become one of the main players in the field of data analytics, cybersecurity, and automation.

DigiByte’s complex architecture is what defined its functionality and made it famous in the crypto-community. Ever since the beginning, the focus of its development was on scalability, decentralization, payment security, and speed. For this, the blockchain has a layered structure and includes:

  • Core Protocol Layer as the Prime Mover. Located at the bottom o the layered structure, it takes care of data management and communication between the nodes and handles all operations taking place on the blockchain.
  • Digital Asset and Public Ledger Layer as the Security and Administrative Hub is where all the data from the network is stored. This layer also hosts the security mechanism that incentivizes miners and prevents meddling with the data.
  • Application Layer as the Front of the DigiByte Architecture is the topmost layer which is the one that users actually interact with. This is also where the dApps and Smart Contract platform will be located once implemented (see below). 

Both DigiByte and Bitcoin operate using Unspent Transaction Output (UTXO), which is a technical method for keeping track of blockchain transactions between accounts. Nevertheless, as of July 2019, DigiByte had over 9 million blocks as compared to Bitcoin’s 600,000 blocks. Besides, DigiByte is 40 times faster than Bitcoin, making it the fastest and longest UTXO blockchain in the world.

Since April 2017, DigiByte has had over 275,000 full nodes downloaded and 15,000 nodes active globally.

DigiByte has a well-defined supply and distribution schedule. A total amount of DGB – 21 billion – will be created and mined gradually in the course of 21 years (from 2014 to 2035). Since there was no DigiByte ICO or any other token distribution event, mining is the only way for new DGB to be produced. 

As opposed to most conventional blockchains, DigiByte uses five cryptographic mining algorithms, which prevents mining centralization. The block time is 15 seconds. Thanks to Segregated Witness (SegWit) implementation, cross-chain transactions, and single confirmation transactions are made possible. A distinct feature of DigiByte transactions is a set limit in size and scope, which leads to an increase in throughput, speed, and efficiency, while also helping maintain security.  

Another characteristic feature of DigiByte is the presence of several functional hardforks:

  • DigiShield is a pioneering asymmetrical difficulty adjustment mining technology created by DigiByte. Conceptually, it protects the blockchain from multipools that mine large amounts of DGB at low difficulty. It is a widely used technology and that be found in the core of many other blockchains (Dogecoin, Startcoin, Zcash, CasinoCoin, CreativeCoin, Granite, Huncoin, Monacoin, AuroraCoin, BitcoinGold, BitTokens, CasinoCoin, CreativeCoin, Granite, Huncoin, Monacoin, Mooncoin, Nautiluscoin, Quatloo, StartCoin, SuperiorCoin, Ubiq, SakuraCoin, Scorecoin, SmartCoin). DigiByte was also the first blockchain to fork from a single proof-of-work (PoW) algorithm to multi-algorithm mining. (Not the first cryptocurrency to use multi-algorithm though – Huntercoin was ahead.)
  • The MultiAlgo hardfork was activated in September 2014 from Myriadcoin source code and allowed for multi-algorithm mining. Its goal was to accommodate different types of existing mining capabilities (dedicated ASIC mining, GPU, and CPU mining) by creating a number of different proof-of-work (PoW) mining methods. Naturally, this allows for a larger number of people to access DigiByte mining pools, therefore creating a more decentralized blockchain featuring the groups of users who were previously unable to mine the coin on its original single-algorithm (Scrypt) fork.
  • MultiShield was activated in December 2014 and served to enable DigiShield across the new MultiAlgo platform and accomplish the same goals on all five mining pools.
  • DigiSpeed was activated in December 2015 and focused on increasing the speed of DigiByte transactions. Besides, the block time was reduced by 50% (15 seconds), and a new block propagation code was added with the help of Microsoft.

Perspectives and takeaways

Going beyond Being a Payment Platform.

The philosophy of DigiByte is built on the belief that focusing solely on payments and transactions is not enough, and by doing so, cryptocurrencies are bound to slowly die out. Instead, DigiByte closely follows the developments in the fields of Cybersecurity, Artificial Intelligence (AI) and IoT (Internet of Things). The DigiByte team believes that the scalability and security of the network are ideal for the use with IoT devices that can number thousands and grow really fast. This is why DGB already has a plan of pairing its blockchain technology with AI for the protection of IoT devices.

The newest release from DigiByte is DigiAssets – the top layer of the DigiByte blockchain that enables the implementation of smart contracts, decentralized applications, and programmable tokens, much like Ethereum. The team believes that DigiByte’s elevated security and scalability offer the ideal base protocol for a platform like DigiAssets. The DigiByte founder Jared Tate was the creator of the first two DigiAssets called DigiTorch and DigiFlame in April 2019. Those are meant to be passed on by different DigiByte community members as they build new projects on the platform.

Apart from constantly developing technical upgrades and improvements for the core protocol, DigiByte launched DigiStats in the autumn of 2019. The aim of DigiStats is to increase mobile and payment processing options, create more fiat and USDT stablecoin pairings on different exchanges, and provide interactive and historical blockchain statistics.

In January 2020, as the network turned six years old, the company launched the DigiByte Foundation which serves to help with fund-raising inside the community.

While the aforementioned plans are still in development, it is worth noting that DigiByte was always willing to expand its technology beyond cryptocurrency. Back in 2017, for instance, DigiByte Gaming division was launched with the aim of promoting digital advertising and user engagement in games through prizes and micropayments delivered in cryptocurrency.

That said, the biggest and most important upcoming plan for DigiByte is still the growth and development of DigiAssets. If all goes according to plan, the entire ecosystem of dapps and ICO will be an integral part of the network.
